text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text above and below a continuous horizontal pen-and-ink drawing that spans the full width; the image occupies the central register with text ‘floating’ above and below. Wide blank margins contain no additional ornament. The visual hierarchy is held by the central continuous narrative, with text clearly separated into upper and lower blocks.

color_scheme.color_usage: Monochrome drawing executed in iron-gall ink. Variations in line density create emphasis on figures and landscape. No pigment. The even tone underscores the sketch-like study character and has aged to a warm sepia. Original lines are well-preserved with minimal fading.

features: Continuous narrative in three horizontal registers
Horizontal movement from left to right

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid freehand quill-pen work with varied stroke weight and occasional rapid “sketch” strokes.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal shading; simple parallel hatching in water waves.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling; no linear perspective. Overlapping figures and landscape lines suggest depth.

reading_order: Left to right, top register to bottom register

scene_relationships.subject: Egyptian chariots and horsemen pursuing Israelites
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: The pursuers are led into the parted sea, which appears in the next register
visual_connections: Figures face right toward next scene

scene_relationships.subject: Chariots overwhelmed by returning waters; Egyptians drowning
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: After destruction of pursuers, Israelites advance on dry land in the lower register
visual_connections: Wave motifs identical to upper register
Drowning figures share same scale as pursuers
Landscape line continues across register boundaries
Broken chariot wheel motif echoes earlier intact wheel

scene_relationships.subject: Israelites walking on dry seabed toward tents
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Concludes the sequence, no further scene
visual_connections: Group of human figures matching earlier procession
Leaders gesturing forward as in first scene

content_theme.scene_description: The drawing comprises three linked scenes in a continuous horizontal narrative. First, on the upper left, a tightly grouped phalanx of Egyptian chariots and horsemen, each with two-wheeled vehicle and cavalryman, advances rightward; figures wear short tunics and carry spears. The middle register shows the same chariots overwhelmed by returning sea waves, their axles broken and drivers flailing as water surges. Below, the lower register depicts a line of Israelite figures, bearded men in long robes, walking across the dry sea floor toward a pair of simple wedge tents; one figure points ahead, guiding the procession. Spatially, the three registers are united by a single sweeping baseline; figures are similar in scale, and depth is suggested by overlapping limbs and vehicles. The Israelites’ robes, rendered by simple pen strokes, indicate fabric folds; the chariots’ wheels and horse harnesses are delineated by confident line work. Tents are shown with taut cloth flaps, and strewn rocks mark the seabed. The overall action moves from left to right, highlighting divine deliverance and the destruction of the Egyptian pursuers. Secondary elements such as the stylized wave patterns reinforce the miracle’s setting, while the absence of color focuses attention on the narrative action.

secular: Egyptian chariots and horsemen in short tunics with spears
Israelite men in long robes walking

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform thickness and creamy surface. Ruling for text visible under magnification.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Very good. Brown-ink drawing remains crisp with minimal fading. Small water stain in upper margin; slight discoloration around edges.
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing in pricking and ruled baselines
Iron-gall ink with varied drying contraction marks
Confident freehand pen strokes indicating master draughtsmanship

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-Carolingian manuscript leaf, executed in Caroline minuscule and featuring a continuous pen-and-ink drawing of the Exodus narrative, reflects a dual liturgical and didactic function typical of monastic Psalters. Produced in a central Frankish scriptorium circa late ninth to early tenth century, its uncluttered, sketch-like style suggests a model book or exemplar for teaching scriptori al draughtsmanship. The monochrome brown ink drawing, carefully aligned to ruled baselines, demonstrates a sophisticated underdrawing technique with precise pricking visible under ultraviolet light. Iconographically, the sequence of Egyptian chariots overwhelmed by returning waters leading to the safe passage of Israelite figures visually amplifies the accompanying psalmic text on divine intervention. In comparison with fully illuminated Psalter of Louis the Pious, this more economical drawing reveals workshop flexibility, where master hands provided rapid narrative sketches for pedagogical or devotional reference. The absence of color concentrates attention on line and composition, highlighting the Carolingian emphasis on clarity and textual primacy. The coherent use of landscape baseline and continuous narrative anticipates later Romanesque band formats, marking a transitional stage in manuscript illustration. Overall, the leaf exemplifies the Carolingian manuscript’s role in theological education, liturgical reading, and the formation of medieval visual exegesis.
